Jonah.Action: No direct actions or statements observed in the excerpt relevant to competence.
Feels frightened and nervous when alone and confronted by pirates, admits to fear.
Defends himself by blaming a friend for teasing and justifies her getting what she deserves.
Looks around the restaurant, takes in the surroundings, recognizes he's alone, and feels frightened.
Reads the menu carefully and notices the odd item 'Compassion' listed with market price.
Startled and scared when pirates slide back the Plexiglas and confront him.
Asks sincerely what compassion means, showing curiosity and openness.
Does not appear or take action in this excerpt; no evidence of skill or capability shown.
Rides regally into the market to deliver God's message, showing responsibility and readiness to help others by bringing important news.
Gives a message that causes fear initially but then reassurance by clarifying it is encouragement, showing care for how his message affects the crowd.
Sings a positive, encouraging song promoting kindness, honesty, prayer, and caring for others; encourages the townspeople to join in and actively engages with them.
Calls out merchants selling undesirable foods based on religious or cultural rules, causing merchants to change their wares, but does so through a lighthearted song rather than harsh confrontation.
Prays nightly and earnestly seeks God's message to deliver.
Expresses confusion and reluctance about going to Nineveh, a city hostile to his people.
Mocks the idea of going to Nineveh, implying God and himself would never go there.

Rejects the call to go to Nineveh, insisting they do not deserve mercy and positioning his own people as the chosen good guys while Nineveh are bad guys; tears map to exclude Nineveh and throws it away.
Lies awake thoughtfully after rejecting the mission, showing some internal conflict and hesitation.
Jonah is greeted warmly by townspeople upon exiting his tent.
Jonah is reluctant and fearful about delivering God's message to Nineveh.
Backs out of tent and is hesitant about delivering God's message, not knowing what to do.
Responds to townspeople's friendly greetings with panic and denial, tries to avoid interaction.
Clearly anxious and tries to run away from people asking him questions.
Starts to panic and denies having any news, acting nervously and anxiously when greeted by townspeople.
Runs away quickly and looks over his shoulder to avoid being followed, showing some situational awareness and urgency.
Runs face first into a map on the street, indicating clumsiness and lack of attention.
Is confused by Scooter's explanation about Nineveh being landlocked, showing a lack of geographical knowledge or preparation.
Erupts in frustration when others assume he's going to Nineveh, clearly states he wants to go the opposite way and chooses a far destination to avoid Nineveh.
Insists money is no object and persistently tries to find a way to go to Tarshish despite others' objections.
Smiles relieved when setting sail with pirates, showing initial ease.
Realizes he is running away from God and looks concerned, showing internal conflict.
Plays ping-pong lethargically and makes no attempt to hit the ball, indicating depression and disengagement from social interaction.
Realizes he is officially running away from God and shows some concern about it.
Stands lethargically while playing ping-pong, makes no attempt to hit the ball, indicating low motivation or engagement.
Rejects the celebration and chooses to walk away listlessly after losing the ping pong game.
Expresses self-doubt and regret quietly when alone, saying 'Oh, what have I done?'
Initially reacts fearfully and suspiciously to the talking pillow bag and Mr. Twisty the worm.
Shows disinterest and disengagement when Khalil introduces himself and talks about his business and motivational tapes.
Turns away and chooses to get some rest rather than engage with Khalil's enthusiasm and attempts at conversation.
Shows disinterest and lack of engagement during conversation with Khalil, not asking questions or showing curiosity.
Confidently states the ship's destination (Tarshish) accurately.
Quickly turns away to rest instead of engaging further with Khalil when he seems to want to converse more.
Tries to hide his smile and responds modestly to Khalil's admiration
His fake modesty fades and he deflates when Khalil praises his closeness to God
Willingly engages with Khalil initially, showing openness and some friendliness
Avoids talking about Nineveh and shows sadness but does not open up
Flattered by Khalil's praise but tries to hide his smile and responds modestly.
Attempts to deflect Khalil's enthusiasm and downplay his celebrity status.
Becomes visibly uneasy and deflates when Khalil emphasizes how reliable he is as a prophet, showing discomfort with the pressure.
Avoids discussing Nineveh when Khalil brings it up, indicating reluctance or avoidance of a difficult topic.
Avoids talking about his feelings and relationship; appears desperate and withdrawn when confronted.
Does not engage with Khalil's friendly attempts to connect and make plans; groans and stares at the wall.
Stares at the wall and groans, unable to speak when confronted with the personal conflict and mission ahead.
Responds with desperation and insistence on needing rest rather than engaging with Khalil's insights or plans.
Closes his eyes, clearly depressed, seeming to avoid or shut down rather than facing his responsibilities.
Responds politely with a thank you when given directions to Tarshish.
Attempts to ignore God's voice by running away and covering his ears.
Struggles against rising water, showing resistance but also denial.
Eventually wakes up groggy and confused to the danger threatening the ship.
Shows concern and panic when the ship is in danger; asks what can be done to help
Gives Pa Grape an 'it's a long story' look, not immediately explaining
Admits fault openly and takes responsibility for his fleeing from God's command.
Loses the card game to the Worm, appearing nervous and ultimately defeated.
Shows humility and self-awareness by acknowledging the danger his actions have caused.
Misjudges the situation initially by running away from his mission and appears overwhelmed by consequences.
Attempts to appear noble and confident when offered an alternative to be thrown overboard, but his response comes off as dry and surprised.
Looks down and catches Khalil's eye, shakes his head sadly and looks pitifully toward the sea.
Interrupts Khalil when he offers technical help with a sarcastic remark.
Offers a resigned look observing the chaos caused by Khalil the Worm, implicitly accepting the situation without anger or blame.
Offers a resigned look, implying acceptance of the situation despite failure by others, showing awareness and composure.
Does not intervene or correct the WORM's faulty procedure despite the obvious risk, potentially indicating passivity or lack of assertiveness.
Gulps nervously but ultimately jumps off the plank into the sea, allowing the sailors to be spared from the storm.
Does not resist or cause trouble for the pirates despite being in a dangerous situation.
Looks nervous but urges the others to keep trying to save him with repeated pleas of 'Hurry! Fellows... please!'
Does not show any frustration or blame towards Pa Grape, Mr. Lunt, or Larry despite their repeated failed attempts to save him
Looks nervous and scared while missing the lifesaver ring multiple times, fails to effectively communicate or take decisive action to save himself.
Recognizes something is in the water and alerts others, showing awareness of his surroundings.
Repeatedly urges others to hurry and help despite unsuccessful attempts to save him, maintains presence of mind under stress.
Swallowed by the giant whale while trying to move toward the boat, showing lack of control over situation.
Sits forlornly and makes a dry, somewhat sarcastic comment about the bowling ball inside the whale.
Sits forlornly inside the whale, dryly remarks on the bowling ball rolling near him.
Dismisses Khalil's attempt to cheer him up and walks away depressed and annoyed.
Responds angrily to Khalil's positive outlook and expresses his despair about being inside the whale.
Acknowledges his wrongdoing and accepts responsibility for disobeying God, feeling remorse.
Responds with surprise and curiosity when addressed kindly and encouraged by the singers; shows openness to their message about forgiveness and God's love.
Startles when hearing voices inside the whale, shows confusion about how they got in.
Recognizes voice as divine messengers and connects the dots about God's involvement.
Looks around nervously when told he has a message, indicating anxiety or uncertainty.
Prays and asks God for forgiveness inside the whale; expresses willingness to obey God despite dislike for the people of Nineveh.
Is terrified along with worm during whale's tumultuous movements, showing vulnerability.
Greets his camel Reginald warmly after ordeal, showing relief and friendliness.
Looks around nervously and continues on despite fear after hearing warnings from crazed man.
Attempts to deliver a message to the city despite hostility and skepticism from the guards.
Nervously tries to explain himself but remains polite and sincere even when guards mock him.
Swallows hard, urges Reginald on, and repeats to himself 'Go in, give the message, get out' to gather courage before facing the guards.
Is clearly nervous and stammers when questioned by the guards; fails to present himself confidently or assertively.
Is caught off guard by guards' questions, unsure how to respond when asked who the message is for.
Tries to explain his purpose despite the hostile reception; attempts to engage with guards rather than retreat.
Responds to the Pirates with confusion and surprise, acknowledges their presence and attempts to understand their situation.
Reluctantly allows the Pirates to involve him in their plan to enter the city despite initial hesitation.
Shows signs of discomfort and a desire to distance himself, not fully embracing the camaraderie or warmth of the group.
Decides to go home after initial effort fails, showing reluctance to continue the mission.
Pauses and reacts confusedly when seeing the pirates unexpectedly returning, showing situational awareness.
Engages with the pirates and listens to their story about being spit out by the whale and trying to deliver the message.
Expresses doubt about entering the city but is open to suggestion when Lunt proposes getting him in through the pirates.
Tries to smile and affirms he sailed halfway across the world with the group despite clearly feeling uneasy and forced.
Questions the accusation against the group, says 'You can't do that!'
Hesitates and is unsure how to respond to the city official's question about being with the men
Looks down confused and panics upon realizing he is tied up with others under a large fish trap, showing concern for the situation and others' safety.
Cries openly with others after embarrassing moment (pumpkin hits his face)
Reacts to punishment (the Slap of No Return) by crying like a baby.
Intervenes to stop punishment and asks to hear the guilty parties' defense
Pleading to the crowd to consider the circumstances with fairness
Intervenes to ask King Twistomer to allow the accused to speak in their own defense, showing quick thinking and advocacy.
Expresses doubt and confusion loudly about how seriously snack food is taken, indicating a lack of understanding of the situation's seriousness at first.
Attempts to reason with the crowd by presenting a logical explanation that the snacks were in plain sight, showing an effort to be persuasive and rational.
Desperately appeals to the City Official to stop harm coming to the Pirates, insists he is not really with them, shares his story honestly despite personal discomfort.
Does not deny the unpleasant smell and appears apologetic about it.
Desperately appeals to the City Official to explain his situation, tries to convince them he was in the belly of a whale, despite panicking.
Uses personal testimony about being in the whale and praying to God to persuade the crowd and the king, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Does not fully notice the reactions around him while making his appeal, indicating some lack of situational awareness.
Delivers a sincere message urging people to stop cheating, lying, and slapping people with fishes to save the city.
Smiles contentedly after delivering the serious message, showing confidence and goodwill.
Struggles to remember the message he is supposed to deliver, stammers and hesitates.
Eventually collects himself and confidently delivers a clear and impactful message that convinces the king and crowd to change their ways.
Smiles contentedly after delivering the message, showing confidence in the result.
Jonah is warmly thanked by Ninevites and responds politely with thanks and farewells.
Jonah internally doubts God’s forgiveness towards Ninevites and hopes for their destruction.
Jonah watches Nineveh expecting their destruction instead of showing mercy or joy at their repentance.
Mourns deeply over the loss of the weed that provided him shade, calling it his friend
Shows frustration and impatience towards the fate of Nineveh, expecting destruction and fire
Unable to answer when questioned about his true motivations and whereabouts, showing possible avoidance or inner conflict
Expresses gratitude to God for a second chance.
Becomes theatrically pouty and wishes he were dead because others also receive a second chance.
Shows reluctance and resistance toward extending mercy and compassion to others as Khalil advocates.
Attempts to stop Khalil from leaving, showing some desire for connection.
Tries to call the worm's name several times with comical attempts, showing persistence and a desire for connection.
Looks smaller and more alone as the worm walks away, indicating vulnerability and loneliness rather than hostility or coldness.
No direct action or statement attributed to Jonah in this excerpt; observes others showing kindness and generosity.
Is remembered as a prophet who survived being inside a whale, which implies resilience and some form of divine competence.
Is primarily depicted through others’ storytelling and not shown taking direct, capable action in the excerpt.
Scowls at the people of Nineveh instead of showing compassion.
Survives the whale and is given a second chance.
Does not want the message of compassion and mercy to be spread.
Asked what compassion is, showing curiosity but confusion about the concept.
Listens with interest when PA Grape offers to illustrate with a story, demonstrating attentiveness.
Arrives regally on his camel, commanding attention as a prophet.
Looks around smartly before addressing the crowd, showing awareness and presence.
Delivers a message with confidence, managing crowd expectations by first causing tension then reassuring them.

Leads the crowd in singing a clear, engaging, and organized message from the Lord, effectively getting merchants to change what they are selling and encouraging townspeople to participate and follow instructions.
Leads townspeople in a friendly, communal song and dance about following God's commands, thanking everyone warmly after the performance.
Leads townspeople in a lively, organized song and dance conveying an important message from God, engaging and motivating them confidently.
Thanks everyone politely and acknowledges the success of the event with confidence.
Decides to go to Tarshish, the furthest place from Nineveh, showing deliberate planning and clear decision-making.
Insists on going to Tarshish despite others explaining it would take weeks and is impractical, showing disregard for others' practical concerns.
Offers money to overcome obstacles and secure passage, demonstrating resourcefulness and confidence.
Not fully listening to advice or considering other options (ignores Scooter's suggestion and map information), indicating a lack of open-mindedness.
Decides to stop playing after losing 2 out of 3 ping pong games and walks away listlessly from the table.
Reflects on his actions with a depressed tone, questioning what he has done, showing some self-awareness.
Uses a bag of grape leaves as a pillow without checking thoroughly and reacts nervously and impulsively when the bag 'speaks,' throwing it against the wall.
Attempts to understand and confront the unexpected talking worm (Khalil) with curiosity and a demand for answers.
Expresses despair and hopelessness about their situation inside the whale, feeling ill and facing the reality of possible death without attempting a solution.
Interrupts Khalil and rejects interaction, showing irritability and emotional instability in a crisis.
Acknowledges his disobedience and the consequences he faces, demonstrating awareness of his responsibilities but lacks proactive problem-solving.
Prays and asks God for forgiveness, commits to obeying if given another chance.
Appears terrified and unprepared while inside the whale during the violent undulation.
Heads straight for Nineveh after being given a second chance, despite warnings and evident danger.
Looks around uncomfortably and nervously continues after hearing a crazed man's warnings of danger ahead.
Tries to maintain a confident front by forcing a smile when questioned by the guard, despite feeling ill and uncomfortable.
Shows confusion and lack of understanding about the significance of the golden ticket and the cheese curls sweepstakes.
Questions the accusation against the group and stands up to the city official, asking what the men have done.
Is unsure how to answer when asked if he is with the accused men, responding hesitantly with 'Well, um... yes, I suppose...'
Challenges the arrest by saying 'You can't do that!' showing some confidence in standing up for the group.
Fails to avoid the guard's attack, resulting in a blackout and capture, indicating a lack of physical readiness or situational awareness.
Realizes confusion and danger upon seeing he cannot move and is tied under a metal fish, shows clear awareness of the situation.
Looks to Pa Grape for help or understanding but appears panicked and unable to free himself or act decisively.
Acknowledges the seriousness of their predicament by stating 'This doesn't look good...', showing situational awareness.
Fails to understand the point of compassion and mercy despite being given a second chance.
Survives being swallowed by a giant whale, indicating resilience.
